This show is one for the ages, a true gem of high production values, (mostly) fantastic storylines of romance and intrigue.

I have pre-ordered S6, like all the other seasons. But I wait, rather impatiently, for PBS/Masterpiece/Carnival to grow up and give its patrons of the high-priced DVD/Blu-Rays versions of the episodes that match what is actually aired on PBS.

I am sick of having the "UK" version pawned on us. The UK version is roughly what is aired on ITV. ITV has commercial breaks played during Downton Abbey (making it a surreal viewing experience with Old El Paso commercials in between dinner scenes, not to mention having the X-Factor as DA's lead-in). These commercials make episodes 2-7 shorter than what viewers see almost everywhere else, including, most notably, the PBS version in the US. Enterprising fans have found this out, noted where the differences are, which does roughly track the amount of time that is lost in the UK to commercials. Why not give US viewers what they expect to see when the purchase a DVD/Blu-Ray/Streaming copy of this - the version they see aired on PBS?

It's weird enough that the DVD/Blu-Ray, etc. are made available mid-season in the US as it is. PBS would already have its edited versions available to be included on the product it's shilling out to fans at Amazon and elsewhere. PBS simply chooses not to, short-changing us all in the process.

It is a continuing disservice to fans that they do not get to own what they see during a PBS broadcast.

Maybe they will release a "US" version of all seasons, costing an arm and leg, of course. Maybe I will buy it. Until then, every single DVD/Blu-Ray review related to Downton Abbey will have 4 stars from me.

Season 6 is finally here and Downton Abbey is finally at its end. After watching all 8 episodes as well as the Christmas special finale, I can definitely say this season is much better than the last two seasons which have been a chore to get through. It is still by no means as lovable as the first two seasons, though.

The year long wait for the new Downton series always seems like an age, especially this year as we knew that it would be the last ever series.  It seems perverse that such a successful series has had to end, however, as the incomparable Maggie Smith said, if you work it out I should be about 110 years old by now!  A slight exaggeration, but you can see where she is coming from since Downton has run from about the time of the Titanic disaster in 1912 all the way to 1925.

The TV series has now finished in the UK and for those of you waiting for the North American showing or DVD, it was an absolute cracker and if you enjoyed the first five series of Downton, you are not going to be disappointed with the final series.  As would be expected, there was a certain amount of tying up of loose ends, but not to an excessive extent.  However we still have the Christmas Special show to air at the end of next month so everyone is waiting in suspense for the final conclusion.  Incidentally if you are impatient to see the last series, although the UK issue is released this month, that will not contain the 2015 Christmas Special whereas the later North American release will.

It is difficult to single out the outstanding performances in series 6 as all the regular players had significant roles.  It was good to see Tom back, and others such as Mrs Patmore, The Bates, Barrow, and Daisy below stairs and, of course, all the Crawley family are in the thick of things.  Maggie Smith, as the Dowager is very much in evidence and her priceless sarcasm includes many a memorable line.  Overall, without dropping in any spoilers, there was romance, tragedy, blackmail, suspense, joy and sorrow.  In other words exactly what you would expect from Downton!

So I'll use this space to address the continued worries over a so-called "American version" of Downton Abbey:

Way back in January 2011, the Daily Mail, a British tabloid that's a hybrid of US Weekly and the National Enquirer, posted an article accusing PBS of editing the first season of Downton Abbey because Americans were apparently too stupid to understand the entail. As the Daily Mail intended, this article set off a storm of accusations and anxieties over whether we Americans were getting the real version the Brits were seeing on ITV. And this story is still being circulated, as seen in the discussion section below.

The only thing PBS edited out of season one was the snuffbox storyline, likely because it was redundant when the stolen wine storyline was exactly the same.

Once the Daily Mail article lied about the reasons for the PBS editing, and Downton Abbey became so popular in the US that PBS was able to attract high quality funding, they not only aired the episodes as they did in the UK, but sometimes added scenes that weren't shown on ITV (since ITV airs commercials and has to cut things to fit around them).

PBS now stamps their Downton Abbey DVDs "UK Version" because people are still passing around the story that they cut the show up liberally. The ironic part is that by only releasing the ITV versions on DVD, you'll never get to see the extra PBS scenes unless you record them as they air.

For a show that for the first five seasons kept you on the edge of your seat with things going wrong, this is a rather cringe-worthy feel-good ending that plays to the audience's sentimentality.  Every time a problem does come up, it's neatly resolved five minutes later.  And the very end is almost laughable the way it provides a happily-ever-after ending for almost everyone.  Seems like love is suddenly springing up everywhere--Edith, Mrs. Patmore, Daisy, Mrs. Crawley, Branson (hinted at, anyway)....The only sad note is Carson's forced retirement, but even that becomes only semi-retirement and provides Barrow with his dream job.  I'm as sentimental as the next person, but it's a bit much.  Oh well...overall, a great show.

I'd give the whole series five stars except for two things - the gay character (Mr Barrow) has no redeeming value and is right out of the Hayes Code stereotyping, including him being a coward. I'm surprised he wasn't killed off after being discovered as a serial killer. Maybe Julian Fellowes is some nutcase Christian, but the reality is this character is inappropriate as presented, and really has no reason to be that way. The same holds true for Denker, the Dowager's ladies maid. I love the actress who plays her, but the character has no redeeming value and no motive for having no redeeming value, unless Fellowes is making some obscure statement about mental health. At least the sole black character wasn't presented as some drug pushing pimp stereotype, and was treated with respect. Likewise with the Jews.

I'm not saying the Crawley family should have embraced homosexuality with historically-inaccurate open arms. But watch the Celluoid Closet documentary and you will see Barrows ticks all the homophobic buttons of the Hayes Code, and I sincerely doubt every gay man in 1920s was a conniving evil coward only seeking to destroy people for no reason.

some love the British accent, the British behavior, the British characterizations, the British sensibilities, the British insouciance, the British class society of the olden days, and the British values as they relate to honor and societal status.  It's all here in the Downton Abbey series, where all of life's pain, joy, thrills, guilt, worry, and love and suspense are found in the aristocratic and the common levels of British society.  Set at the "big house", Downton Abbey offers splendid character development of both the wealthy as well as the servants, as a captivating in-house duality survives a fading way of life in war torn Europe.  Modernization is on the rise, as electricity finds its way into society, followed by telephones and telegraphs, automobiles and airplanes, and the rise of the proletariat slowly closes in on the old money families who survive in their castle-like estates.  Lots of stories within stories within stories, and interesting relationships between classes and among classes are artfully crafted using well developed characters who garner your attention and your favor by their unique personalities.  It's quality stuff, folks, with intelligent discussions and credible acting, and it simply pulls you into their world.

My brain wants to end the reigns of kings and queens, titles and human oppression and class ranks.  But my heart never stops craving the romance and fairy tale lives of the privileged.  Downtown Abbey swept me into the confluence of the rich and powerful as they managed the people that served them.  All the while showering me with the masterpiece paintings, antique furnishings, dinner place settings, etiquette
and manners plus the reminder of what civil discourse is.  The gardens and country location were also an added bonus to the excellent story, superb actors, and breath taking representation of "how it felt" to hear the Titantic sunk, that WWI began as well as the consequences that followed these events.  It is a rare find to have a tv series more intriguing than a book, but Downton Abbey rises to that occasssion.
